lines.text: There is something much more important than keeping alive, and that is knowing that you have lived.

[Coldly]
Please say what you have to say to me and go.
If that's the way you want it.
How else would you think I'd want it?
Well, I hoped things might have changed.
Why?
That you might have thought it over.
And say all right, Ellen, no hard feelings? It was a fair fight and the best man or, rather, girl won?
My conscience is clear, Maud.
You know I think you mean it.

[to Ellen]
Maybe I'm slow. Maybe you can explain it to me. Nobody knows better than you that I was in love with Dan. And suddenly without any warning he married you. How should I feel?

Don't think Ellen isn't going to know about it. You think I'd let her have you without knowing why? Without knowing that you didn't love her? Oh, no, darling. I'm not as noble as all that. Ellen may get well. If she does, she may wish she hadn't.
Maud, If I thought you'd say anything to Ellen, I'd kill you.
Do you? We'll see. Oh, don't worry. I won't SAY anything. Thank for the coffee, Dan.
[She leaves the restaurant]
I 'm going to be a spinster, father. All my life. But there is an awful lot to be said for it.

[to Ellen]
I hate seeing you giving in. I don't think you're plain, my dear. Not at all. I think you are very... special. Very special, my dear.
I made a mistake coming here. I assure you I never will again.
You needn't.

[Joyously taking in the wintery scenery]
Oh, it's not real. I'm not real. Nothing's real!
I am!
Oh, yes, you are. Thank heavens you are!

[to Ellen]
That's why you're really here, isn't it? 'Cause the year's dragging out fast. Only a couple of months left and you're scared to death. Well, Ellen, do you think I've given up?
I think you must be out of your mind. I feel sorry for you, Maud.
